comments.commentBody: How about the ways Israel treats the Palestinian people?

You seem to take delight in refuting every comment that is critical of your original post in which you inferred that all of the protestors in Ferguson are racist (although you now say that only "some" of the protestors are racist). Which is quite ironic and hypocritical of you given your propensity for grand pronouncements about how "everyone" is to blame for racism and that everyone needs to do a little "soul-searching" to solve the problem of racism. I suggest you start with yourself, take your own advice and stop indiscriminately labeling black protestors as racist.

Also, it sounds like you have your facts all mixed up. They trotted out a black police captain as window-dressing, really, nothing more, but he managed to help diffuse an extremely tense situation--he even marched with the protestors at one point. But this was all after the police chief trotted out the tank, the machine guns, the tear gas, and the police in combat gear. The protestors are well aware that it was the police chief who has refused to release any police reports on the incident except for irrelevant videotape that showed the victim stealing a box of cigars, as if to prove Michael Brown was merely a thug who deserved to be gunned down, case closed. And you wonder why the police chief is "vilified."

Thanks for your opinion TS.

Others disagree with you too.

In reading this I realize that the ultimate irrationality is the conviction that rationality can prevail over that new word I just learned from the article, "fideistic"

It plays out in this country in our pledge of allegiance, as explored in this essay:

http://alrodbellreferences.blogspot.com/2014/09/education-indoctrination...
Because Islam denies the divinity of Christ is can't ever be considered an extension of it.

I guess "Innocent until proven guilty" extends to everyone except Michael Brown, right?  Now he's a thug because he stole some cigars and shoved a store clerk.  Where's his trial?  Where's his right to testify?  Oh, he doesn't get a trial because he's dead.  He's also been judged by the media, by the police captain who, days later, decided to release the surveillance video from the convenience store.  Michael Brown got less than a trial in court, less than a train in the media.  He was found guilty by Darren Wilson was was summarily executed. But I guess that's justice in your eyes.

You have got to be kidding. He didn't have to apologize but he did have to admit that his officer used extraordinary force against and unarmed man who was guilty of no more than stealing a few cigars (which the officer had no knowledge of at the time he pulled the trigger). SIX shots into an unarmed man who had not done anything to harm the officer, the store owner, or anyone else. You have got to be kidding. That, to me is nothing but manslaughter at the least.

Train your men, don't give them license to kill.

@ gemli
"Thanks for highlighting these quotes. They do the job with great economy of language."

That's why I use them. Who needs 1,500 characters to say what someone else has in far less?

Want more? It's my own lifelong collection. Feel free to use.
http://from-the-doghouse.com/CANINE_QUOTES/Anasagasti/Anasagasti_List.html

"I am not merely a habitual quoter but an incorrigible one. I am, I may as well face it, more quotatious than an old stock-market ticker-tape machine, except that you can't unplug me."
~ JOSEPH EPSTEIN
(b.1937)
American essayist, short story writer, and editor, and from 1974 to 1998 the editor of The American Scholar magazine.

I wonder what all the commentators talking about the looting in Ferguson would make of the Boston Tea Party, where so-called American patriots destroyed massive amounts of tea being carried by some blameless boat captain who had nothing to do with British policies about taxation. Just because a movement spurs some idiots to destroy private property does not negate the validity of the movement. If it did, then we wouldn't have a country in the first place.

Why ask of Islam something that you don't ask of Christians and Jews? The Bible and Christian history are replete with wholesale slaughters of "heretics," and I don't recall a "formal and explicit repudiation" of such violence from either religion.
A good number of those Jews in Arab countries were murdered,before they had the opportunity to move to other countries.

There is some whitewash going on here. Islam uses the term "dhimmi" to refer to "people of the book," i.e. Jews and Christians. They are a step above pagans so are not necessarily forced to convert or die, but they must live in an inferior status to their Muslim leaders (pay a special tax and engage in deferential behaviors). One has only to look at the historical treatment of Jews in Arab countries (most have since emigrated to Israel and other countries) and the current treatment of Christians in the Arab world to see that the inferior "dhimmi" are not treated with respect or appreciation for the commonality of their traditions with Islam.

I'm Jewish. There is like one metion of the afterlife in Judaism. Our belief system is in no way based on an afterlife. Get your facts straight. Nothing wrong with believing in an afterlife anyway... as long as you don't use that belief to hurt anyone.

@ gemli
"I recommend that you read the bible to get the full picture of the moral code it offers."

Here's another, just for you (& Carl R,).

“It ain’t those parts of the Bible that I can’t understand that bother me, it is the parts that I do understand.” ~ MARK TWAIN

"I always have a quotation for everything - it saves original thinking."
~ DOROTHY L. SAYERS
(1893 – 1957)
English crime writer, poet, playwright, essayist, literary critic, translator of Dante's Divine Comedy

I read too much.

“I was born with a reading list I will never finish.” ~ MAUD CASEY

Neither will my quotes collection.

"A book of quotations can never be complete." ~ ROBERT M. HAMILTON
The Hospital for Sick Children
Section Head, Electrophysiology, Cardiology; University of Toronto Professor, Department of Paediatrics
There are so many books written on that topic that it would be pointless to rehash them here.
which is why, ultimately, judiasm is the superior faith. ( I am not jewish) It allows for alternative thoughts.

It's one incident that haopens multiple tines each day. Black men are far more likely to have their car searched (3 times that of a white man) and more likely to be stopped in the first place.

It's not one incident, it's a boiling over of many incidents that just don't seem to stop.

http://m.dailykos.com/story/2014/08/24/1324132/-How-Often-are-Unarmed-Bl...

Where is the similar outrage about the daily killings BY black people OF black people in "black neighborhoods" in America? Why aren't the houses of Chicago's gangsters looted and burned and robbed after they spend every weekend, holiday, summer night shooting their fellow citizens? Black residents often decry the absence of businesses and jobs in black neighborhoods. The people who start businesses in areas where they have a high likelihood of being looted, robbed and killed deserve Medals of Honor, not attacks by angry hordes! Nobody here will believe me, but I personally know many white people who have been "wrongly" stopped by police. So what?! Sometimes the police stop people on mistaken bases or maybe to prevent a possible crime they thought might be occurring.  Get over the constant perception that black citizens are always victimized by police and start to consider the kind of victimization going on in "inner cities" at the hands - and guns - fellow black residents!
Black men are also far more likely to commit crimes. While this does excuse searching every black man's car, it is still an awkward fact that needs to be factored into to equation.

Why is there so much attention being paid to this anyway.  Blacks make up only 12% of the population and yet one incident consumes the nation for over a month?  I'm more than tired of hearing the whining from one very small minority.    Give it a rest.

Rc-- you are 100% right. I am a believer, but would never be part of one of these male-based religions. god is with us everywhere, through the bounty of nature and our own ability to do good in the world. Surely Jesus did walk the earth, and is a superior man among men, but the son of god? the birth son of a virgin? ridiculous.

@ Maani
• "Gemli, I'm sorry to be so harsh, but your statement above is simply as ignorant as it is arrogant."

It is the arrogance of piety that is based on ignorance and there is nothing more ignorant and arrogant than piety.

Those who have no valid arguments must eventually resort to insults.

"PIETY, n. Reverence for the Supreme Being, based upon His supposed resemblance to man."
~ AMBROSE BIERCE
from "The Devil's Dictionary"

I spent a couple of years collecting news items about moderate Muslims denouncing barbarism. Most of these were not covered by the NYtimes or any other Western News outlets. Check out the link below.

http://muslimbuddhist.blogspot.com/search/label/Muslimoutrage

Recently, The NYTimes did mention that around 200 prominent Muslim Clerics in England denounced the beheadings by ISIS. These days, even Al Qaeda and Iran are denouncing ISIS and Boko Haram.
Thank you, Nancy! I thought I was the only one who didn't "get' it!
So I'm going to sound stupid but I don't care.  Would someone please translate this interview into dumbed down English so that I have a fighting chance to understand what Sajjad Rizvi is saying.

Professor Rizvi understands that some things are really not complicated and he probably gave the best answer he could given the circumstances.

Look at the life of Muhammed, "the Seal of the Prophets". There you will find your answer.

This is one of the more disappointing articles in the series.  Rizvi steps briefly out of the ivory tower to respond with inpenetrable answers to straight questions, and then completely sidesteps the question of why Islam is infested with people and groups that subjugate women and violate their human rights.
Yes not philosophical and reading it looks like we got back in the Middle Ages before the enlightment.Can see this professor sitting behind a big table and deciding who is getting burned today.

Socrates asked questions that pressed the other person to question their own presuppositions. Dr. Gutting seems content to ask questions that merely allow the other person to enumerate them.

These are not philosophical conversations. Informative, yes. But not in the least philosophical.

"I think he is discussing the ideal, rather than how the Muslim faith is currently practiced."

Of course. That is EXACTLY what he is doing. That needs to be done somewhere, as many people (including many commenters here) repeatedly say that Islam is an evil religion even in it's best possible form. What better place to have a discussion on this topic than in the NYtimes Philosophy column?

Sajjad Rizvi is the ultimate religious revisionist.  He flips time to justify the preeminence of Muslim teaching.  To bad he never read the Greek Philosophers, Islamic philosopher Avicenna obviously read them, he plagiarized their explanation of God perfectly.

...and therein lies the problem. If people cannot be bothered to vote, or to even be registered to vote, or to take an active part in the management of their respective communities, the management and direction they have is of their own doing - whether it be local, county, state or federal.
